Ken,

The concept of "NEAT", that you have shared with the rest of us, is a=
 
worthy and substantial contribution worthy of praise. And I have 
openly =
stated as much on more than one occasion. But as I am sure 
that you are aw=
are, a concept once let loose, is free to become more 
that what may have b=
een originally envisioned. 

I am indeed aware of the work involved in usin=
g NEAT for everyday 
engineering tasks, and making substantial upgrades to =
the source code 
infrastructure to unlock its potential (i.e. greater than =
a man-year).

I'm confident in the statement that each proposed update sugg=
ested to 
date has already been accomplished (on NEAT, not HyperNEAT). It w=
ould 
be an error to assume otherwise. So I have more than a concept of 
wh=
ats involved.

The problem, if you want to characterize it as such, is that=
 my 
efforts are directed towards everyday engineering tasks which are not =

public in nature, and the burden of writing papers is substantially 
great=
er than just the writing. The experiments are the everyday jobs 
that need =
to get done.

Your efforts are not unappreciated. But when you put somethin=
g 
forward with associated claims, its reasonable to assume that you 
have =
done your homework and are in a position to answer reasonable 
questions as=
 they relate to your claims.

Asking questions such as:

1) What benchmarks=
 against known quantities, have you made 
comparisons against your claims, =
to help us understand where in the 
AI landscape we should place your claim=
s,

2) What computational cost comparisons have you performed against 
othe=
r known quantities, to help us understand what the costs of your 
claims ar=
e.

These are not adversarial questions. They are the normal types of 
ques=
tions that are routinely addressed in the body of a technical 
paper or pre=
sentation making various claims.

If you fail to answer the questions up fr=
ont in the technical 
presentation/paper itself, it is reasonable to expect=
 follow-on 
questions in an attempt to nail these issues down. If you negle=
ct to 
answer these questions, it is also a reasonable expectation others 
=
will wonder why.

It is my opinion that the concept of NEAT has so much mor=
e potential 
than you have exercised publically to date. 

For whatever you=
r reasons are, perhaps as simple as alignment with 
research interests, you=
 have left a lot on the table. And that is 
your right. It would just be mo=
re helpful to all if you would be more 
forthcoming in regards to the bound=
s of your agenda, and provide 
reasonable answers to questions related to y=
our claims and 
presentations, so that they may be promptly and properly cl=
assified, 
rather than discovering them after the fact in a protracted mann=
er.

Nobody said being the big dog was easy!

Respectfully,
Andy Carl

s

wish).

d writing papers.

one is 
hiding

not

 having answered every question that you have and performed every

ent that you personally believe we should ever perform, why 
not

ore like, "It would be interesting to see if..."  or "One

like to perform is..."  or "An interesting question 
is

her words, what is accomplished by your aggressive,

nor?

=
> interesting quote on scientific research.  To paraphrase: "Good
> scienti=
fic research answers hard questions.  However, the best
> scientific resear=
ch raises entirely new questions that we never 
could
> have even asked bef=
ore."  Think of quantum physics.  The uncertainty
> principle has led to en=
dless discussion of paradoxes and
> impossibilities, with no end in sight, =
but we do not see people
> accusing Heisenberg of trying to hide the "truth=
."  Instead, it is a
> credit to his discovery that we are now asking such =
profound 
questions.

e and drop the

to speak 
to

ly hope 
to
